title: How to Remove a Bee Stinger

steps.title: Call emergency medical help if you have severe allergic symptoms.
steps.content: Call emergency medical help if you have severe allergic symptoms. If you have a history of severe allergic reactions to bee stings and carry an epinephrine auto injector, known as EpiPen, use it immediately. [1] X Research source If you are experiencing any of the following symptoms, get emergency medical attention [2] X Research source : Dizziness or faintness Difficulty breathing Swollen tongue Hives

steps.title: Scrape across the stinger using a flat edge.
steps.content: Scrape across the stinger using a flat edge. Use the edge of a credit card, your fingernail, or a blunt knife to scrape over the stinger, which looks like a small black dot. [3] X Research source Scraping across will actually pull the stinger out and to the side. Scraping across the stinger prevents the venom sack from releasing more venom down into the sting. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Apply an ice pack.
steps.content: Apply an ice pack. The site of the sting will become inflamed and start to swell. Applying ice will numb any pain and keep the swelling down. [5] X Research source If you were stung on your leg or arm, elevate the limb. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Apply hydrocortisone cream.
steps.content: Apply hydrocortisone cream. Gently wash the site with mild soap and water. Then, apply a thin layer of hydrocortisone cream to minimize any reaction you might have. For a more natural treatment, you can mix baking soda and water until it forms a thick paste. Spread this over the sting site. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Use honey.
steps.content: Use honey. If you don't have hydrocortisone on hand, spread pure honey over the sting site. Place gauze or a small cloth over it and let it sit for up to an hour before rinsing off. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Apply toothpaste.
steps.content: Apply toothpaste. Toothpaste is another natural alternative to neutralize the venom of a bee sting. Simply dab a little toothpaste over the sting site, place gauze or a small cloth over it, and let it sit for 20 to 30 minutes. Then, rinse the toothpaste off. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Take acetaminophen or ibuprofen.
steps.content: Take acetaminophen or ibuprofen. This will help relieve some of the pain. Be sure to follow the package instructions regarding dosage. For children, consult with your pediatrician for appropriate dosing of acetaminophen or ibuprofen.

steps.title: Take an antihistamine.
steps.content: Take an antihistamine. This may reduce the severity of a reaction. You can take something like Benadryl (diphenhydramine) or apply calamine lotion to reduce itchiness. [10] X Research source
